review.title: Simulating Ability: Representing Skills in Games
review.abstract: Throughout the history of games, representing the abilities of the various agents acting on behalf of the players has been a central concern. With increasingly sophisticated games emerging, these simulations have become more realistic, but the underlying mechanisms are still, to a large extent, of an ad hoc nature. This paper proposes using a logistic model from psychometrics as a unified mechanism for task resolution in simulation-oriented games.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: One of the most basic concepts in games is the representation of agents, units acting on behalf of a player, and the simulation of their abilities. Take, for example, the various chess pieces and the moves they are capable of; or the troops in the game Risk [1] and their offensive and defensive strengths, represented by the number of dice being rolled. In previous games such as these, game mechanics tended to treat skills in a more abstract and simplified way, but as games have become more lifelike, so has the simulation of skills. An important line of development in this area began with roleplaying games at the table, such as the original Dungeons & Dragons [2], and continues to this day, with computer games requiring sophisticated skills.

sections.heading: 2 Skills and Abilities in Games
sections.text: In this section, I will briefly discuss some existing approaches to modeling skills. I will start with a variety of models used in tabletop role-playing games, partly motivated by the fact that the descriptions of these models Xiv: 130 7.02 01v2 [cs.GT] 2 6Ju l 2 are much more readily available than those included in the proprietary game code, and partly by the fact that "most [computer role-playing games] use a system based on an old paper [role-playing game] to manage their game mechanics." [3, p. 358] After outlining the main models, I will describe some mistakes in the one most commonly used and outline an alternative.

sections.heading: 2.1 Some Classic Approaches
sections.text: A review of published role-playing games shows that a few mechanisms are by far the most common difficulty level. There are significant variations in the details, but nevertheless, a few main models can be distilled. 1Uniform scale. The most popular mechanics is the uniform scale. Although there are different implementations in terms of skill dice, the underlying model is this: skill and difficulty are both represented on the same scale, and the probability of success is a linear function of their difference. A common implementation treats the skill as a fixed probability (or a fixed value on a uniform random scale), and the difficulty as an additive modifier. A uniformly random value is then generated using dice, and if this value is equal to or lower than the modified skill, the action is a success. Another frequent implementation is to allow the skill as an additive modifier on the uniform level of the dice, which increases the difficulty level, of course, to treat the difficulty of the dice that increases.

sections.heading: 2.2 The Problem With Percentiles
sections.text: A superficial analysis, therefore, seems to suggest that a bonus of + 10% is clearly more useful to anyone with a skill of 90% or less than those who are more skillful. Instead, we could consider an unlimited scale in which + 10 really always means + 10, for example. If we ignore randomness and assume that the skill level is all that matters to the result, a skill level of a always beats a skill level (or difficulty level) of b if a > b. In a sense, this is the assumption underlying the so-called Guttman scales, and the model discussed in the following sections is an extension to these to take into account random variations of different kinds.

sections.heading: 3.2 IRT and Rasch Models
sections.text: The model we have derived by looking at skills and degrees of difficulty as strength of proof is actually the one commonly known as the one-parameter logistics model, or 1PL, in the field of psychometric.4 This model was originally introduced by Rasch [5], but has since become a basis for both the so-called invariant measurement in the social sciences [10] and the item-response theory of psychological tests [11].The requirements of invariant measurement limit us to using a sigmoid probability function on an additive scale, as discussed in the introduction. It is possible, say, to use a probit scale, but the logit model is far more common. While a very important reason for this is its ease of calculation, as we have seen in the previous section, there are also philosophical and methodological reasons for favouring it. This use of a logistic distribution can also be found elsewhere.
